titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to "Stanford - The True Source of Knowledge"
titlestmt.author: Daniel Hartwig

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

note.p: This encoded finding aid is compliant with Stanford EAD Best Practice Guidelines, Version 1.0.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit

did.head: Overview
did.abstract: This film concerns the student experience at Stanford University in the mid 1960s and includes interviews with faculty and students. Subjects discussed include intellectual life at Stanford, relationships between male and female students, fraternity life, student activism and protests, the Civil Rights movement, and the 1964 presidential election. Two unnamed students who participated in Stanford's Project South are among the students interviewed. Campus locations in the film include class rooms, the Bookstore, the Computation Center, Tresidder Union, KZSU studio, White Plaza, and the Library. There is also some footage from student rallies at UC Berkeley.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94304-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: "Stanford - The True Source of Knowledge" (V0080). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

altformavail.head: Alternative Formats
altformavail.p: Original 16mm film housed in : Film Collection, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Sketch
bioghist.p: Rubbo earned his MA in communications at Stanford University in 1966; this film was his thesis project.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Collection
scopecontent.p: This film concerns the student experience at Stanford University in the mid 1960s and includes interviews with faculty and students. Subjects discussed include intellectual life at Stanford, relationships between male and female students, fraternity life, student activism and protests, the Civil Rights movement, and the 1964 presidential election. Two unnamed students who participated in Stanford's Project South are among the students interviewed. Campus locations in the film include class rooms, the Bookstore, the Computation Center, Tresidder Union, KZSU studio, White Plaza, and the Library. There is also some footage from student rallies at UC Berkeley.
